div.div: Chaper 3: The first level of Reading: Elementary Reading

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 123px; height: 1px; padding-top: 340px; margin-left: 1511px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 18px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 238px; height: 1px; padding-top: 690px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 18px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font: All reading is active. Reading, like listening, involves an individual receiving communication. The are many types of communication to be received. Each type requires different skill levels of receiving the communication. How well a reader comprehends and understands what is being communicated by the writer determines how active the reading is.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 800px; margin-left: 269px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Reading for information and reading for understanding are the two goals of reading expository works. Reading for information involves reading facts and gaining more knowledge. The reader does not have to work to understand what is being read because the material is already packaged to be understood or is already at the same comprehension level of the reader. Reading for understanding requires the reader to initially not understand the subject of the reading. The read must use nothing other than reasoning and previous experience to understand the material. The reader must be analytical of the material.

switch.text: Reading for information and reading for unders...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 815px; margin-left: 619px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: There are two types of learning. One type is learning by instruction. A teacher will guide a student to understanding material. However, the student must still comprehend what is shared by the teacher by using reasoning. Learning by discovery is when an individual learns through observation and reasoning. Like reading, both forms of learning are active.

switch.text: There are two types of learning. One type...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 238px; height: 1px; padding-top: 805px; margin-left: 899px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Reading is learning by instruction except the teacher is absent. If a reader does not understand what is being communicated by the author, the reader must use reasoning and previous experience to gain understanding of the reading material. Reading is similar to learning by discover because the teacher is absent. You can refer to reading as learning by aided discovery.

switch.text: Reading is learning by instruction excep...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 298px; height: 1px; padding-top: 725px; margin-left: 1424px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Lucida Console; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: There are 4 levels of reading. The first level is elementary reading. This is the process of going from non-literacy to knowing what a sentence says. The second level of reading is inspectional reading. This includes systemically skimming and prereading. This level usually determines what a book is about and outlines the book's structure. The third level of reading is analytical reading. A reader gains understanding and ask many analytical questions. The fourth and last level of reading is syntopical reading. This level of reading is when a reader seeks to gain understanding about a topic from multiple books. The levels of reading are hierarchical in nature. Higher levels of reading include the lower levels of reading.

switch.text: There are 4 levels of reading. The first level is...
